g.text: he Pleistocene climate is characterized by signi
interglacial changes in high-latitude ice volume
. All these variables inherently interacted to generate a
remarkable transition of the ice-age cycles from 41-kyr to 100-kyr
cycles between 1.2 and 0.7 Ma, called the mid-Pleistocene tran-
. The MPT might be triggered by a nonlinear
is particularly apparent in numerous proxy indicators that are
sensitive to changing glacial boundary conditions
middle and low latitudes, however, the proxies of monsoon-
induced wind and hydroclimate changes in the Arabian Sea and
East Asia display prominent precession cycles during the middle-
Simulations with different climate models show that global
monsoon changes are sensitive to changes in insolation, CO
summer monsoon variation was induced by combined effects
roles of the insolation and coupled ice/CO
orbital-scale monsoon variability remain controversial due to
the spatial divergence and complexity of the proxy sensitivity
) of a thick loess sequence from the
northwestern Chinese Loess Plateau (CLP), a region sensitive to
tratigraphy and pedostratigrahpy, together with burial dating,
provide a reliable chronology of the loess
accumulated over the past ~1.7 Ma. Loess
monsoon proxy, offers novel insights into Pleistocene
monsoon variability and dynamics. Unlike the conventional
expression of the MPT, our results reveal a compelling transition
of the dominant rhythm in coupled monsoon
from 23-kyr to combined 23-, 41-, and 100-kyr cycles across
. CLP climate is characterized by seasonal
changes in temperature and precipitation. Summer is the warm
and humid season due to the in
which transports heat and water vapor from the low-latitude
oceans. The summer precipitation from May to September con-
tributes to the annual precipitation by 60
winter is the cold and dry season associated with strong winter
monsoon wind, which is linked to the Siberian
pressure system. The winter monsoon transports vast of dust
particles from inland Asia to the downwind CLP. Therefore,
Chinese loess, as a unique continental archive, can document
multi-scale monsoon variability linked to past climate changes in
above sea level) is located at the depositional center of modern
dust storms on the northwestern CLP (Fig. 1). A 430-m core
was retrieved from the highest terrace of the Yellow River
near Jingyuan County. The JY core consists of a 427-m loess
deposit underlain by a 3-m gravel layer. A 40-m outcrop was
excavated nearby to collect parallel samples spanning the last
glacial cycle. Continuous U-channel and discrete
cube samples were taken from the split cores for alternating-
eld and thermal demagnetization measurements, respectively
(Methods). Three quartz samples were chosen from the under-
Fig. 1). Powder samples were taken at 10-cm intervals for
ments and demagnetization spectra indicate that the JY loess
sediments contain dominantly coarse-grained domain magnetite,
which records the primary detrital remanent magnetization
(Supplementary Figs. 2 and 3). Paleomagnetic results reveal that
the Brunhes/Matuyama (B/M) boundary is recorded at the S
boundary and the Jaramillo subchron is located within S
Location of JY loess core and representative loess pro
les on the Chinese Loess Plateau (CLP). Black dots denote four classic loess pro
have been investigated intensively as the Quaternary stratotype sections
. Red dot indicates the Jingyuan loess pro
le accumulated on the ninth terrace
of the Yellow River in the northwestern CLP
